title: Graphing Single-Variable Inequalities

concept.what_is_it: An inequality tells us where a variable can live on the number line (not just one value).
concept.kid_friendly_explanation: Imagine the number line is a road. The circle shows the 'starting spot' and the arrow shows which way you're allowed to travel.

key_points: First, isolate the variable like an equation.
When you multiply or divide by a negative, flip the inequality sign.
Open circle for $<$ or $>$; filled circle for $\le$ or $\ge$.
Shade (draw an arrow) to the right for
You can also write answers in interval notation.
kid_friendly_explainer: Think of an inequality like $x > 3$ as a rule for where you can be on a number line road. The number 3 is a checkpoint, and the inequality tells you which direction you're allowed to go.

When you see $x > 3$, it means you can be anywhere to the RIGHT of 3 (but NOT exactly at 3). We draw an open circle at 3 to show 'you can't stop here' and an arrow to the right to show 'keep going this way!'
But if you see $x \ge 3$, now you CAN stop at 3! We use a filled circle to show 'this spot is allowed' and still point right for all the other allowed spots.
The tricky part: when you multiply or divide BOTH sides by a negative number, the inequality sign flips! It's like turning around on the road—greater becomes less, and less becomes greater.
step_by_step: Place an open/closed circle at the boundary number.
Draw an arrow in the correct direction.
Optionally write the solution set in interval notation.

walkthrough: Place an open circle at 4 (because it's $>$, not $\ge$)
Draw an arrow to the right (greater means bigger numbers)
Place a filled circle at 5 (because of $\le$)
Draw an arrow to the left (less than means smaller numbers)
Solution: all numbers less than or equal to 5
Draw an arrow to the left
FLIP the inequality sign when dividing by negative!
Draw an arrow to the left

mini_examples.work: Open circle at $4$, arrow to the right.
Filled circle at $5$, arrow to the left.
Divide by $-2$ and flip: $x\le -3$ Filled circle at $-3$, arrow left.

tips: Greater = right; Less = left (think Go Right for Greater).
Check a test point (like $0$) to confirm the shading direction.
Keep fractions and decimals carefully—boundary placement matters!
teacher_notes: Greater = right; Less = left (think 'Go Right for Greater').
Check a test point (like $0$) to confirm the shading direction.
Keep fractions and decimals carefully—boundary placement matters!
Remember: Open circle for strict inequalities ($<$ or $>$), filled circle for inclusive ($\le$ or $\ge$).
When multiplying or dividing by a negative number, ALWAYS flip the inequality sign.
Interval notation: Use parentheses $()$ for open circles, brackets $[]$ for filled circles.
For compound inequalities, you may need to show multiple regions on the number line.
common_mistakes: Forgetting to flip the sign when multiplying/dividing by a negative.
Using a filled circle for $>$ or $<$ (should be open).
Shading the wrong direction because the boundary is negative.

easy.directions: Graph each inequality on a number line and write in interval notation.

items.solution: Open circle at $2$, arrow right. Interval: $(2,\infty)$
Filled circle at $-1$, arrow left. Interval: $(-\infty,-1]$
Open circle at $5$, arrow left. Interval: $(-\infty,5)$
Filled circle at $0$, arrow right. Interval: $[0,\infty)$

medium.directions: Solve the inequality, then graph and write in interval notation.

items.solution: $x\ge 7$ → Filled circle at $7$, arrow right. Interval: $[7,\infty)$
$x<5$ → Open circle at $5$, arrow left. Interval: $(-\infty,5)$
$x\le -8$ → Filled circle at $-8$, arrow left. Interval: $(-\infty,-8]$
$x> -2$ → Open circle at $-2$, arrow right. Interval: $(-2,\infty)$

challenge.directions: Watch for negative coefficients! Remember to flip the inequality.

items.solution: Divide by $-3$ and flip: $x\ge -4$ → Filled circle at $-4$, arrow right. Interval: $[-4,\infty)$
$-2x>-4\Rightarrow x<2$ (flip!) → Open circle at $2$, arrow left. Interval: $(-\infty,2)$
$\dfrac{1}{2}x\ge 2\Rightarrow x\ge 4$ → Filled circle at $4$, arrow right. Interval: $[4,\infty)$
Divide by $-0.2$ and flip: $x> -3$ → Open circle at $-3$, arrow right. Interval: $(-3,\infty)$

extreme.directions: Advanced problems with fractions, absolute values, and word problems.

items.solution: $3-2x\le -5\Rightarrow -2x\le -8\Rightarrow x\ge 4$ (flip!) → Filled circle at $4$, arrow right. Interval: $[4,\infty)$
$x-3>2\;\text{ or }\;x-3<-2\Rightarrow x>5\;\text{ or }\;x<1$ → Open circles at $1$ and $5$. Interval: $(-\infty,1)\cup(5,\infty)$

items.hint: A temperature $t$ is 'safe' if it is at least $-2^\circ$C but below $6^\circ$C.
items.solution: Filled circle at $-2$, open circle at $6$, shade between. Interval: $[-2,6)$
$x+4\le -7.5\Rightarrow x\le -11.5$ (flip!) → Filled circle at $-11.5$, arrow left. Interval: $(-\infty,-11.5]$

self_check.question: When must you flip $<$/$>$/$\le$/$\ge$?
choices: When you multiply or divide by a negative number
self_check.answer: When you multiply or divide by a negative number.
